annotation.TEXT: Today we have a rather interesting case. I had actually heard of this fan game a while back, but never really looked into it until I visited the Cutstuff board's fan game collection topic (where some of my other playthroughs were apparently embedded for examples). This particular game was archived on there, so I figured it was time to take a closer look at it.

This game tries to set up an "original" story and characters. Despite not having Mega Man himself, it still boils down to lifting every other basic aspect from the series (or at least, as much as it can). That's not to say that I don't mind concepts like that. Rokko-Chan, RKS, and elements of Shovel Knight turned out really good. This game, on the other hand, has some issues...

Ape Bot is a bit more annoying to deal with than most of the other bosses, mainly since he tends to stay out of your range by clinging onto the high ceiling (although thankfully, he doesn't stay up there for long). The other problem is with his quake attack, which I honestly don't know if it's even possible to avoid it or not.

Anyways, the basic run-down: Rockbot plays like a faster, clunkier version of Mega Man. He can pretty much do anything the Blue Bomber could from MM5 to MM8, meaning he has a chargeable buster and a slide (which you can perform indefinitely by holding down the button, thereby zipping through portions of the level).

Aside from the downright bizarre designs for the "Robot Masters," I can tell you that what looked like a password back there was completely unnecessary. If there's one good thing about this game, it's that it actually auto-saves every time you beat a stage.

Don't bother with the derpy-looking Rhino. They're practically the toughest thing in the game (even more-so than most of the bosses). They have two different projectiles, and they can endlessly spawn smaller enemies. Just slide through them and never look back.

Right off the bat, you can probably tell what's wrong with the gameplay and the overall engine. It's pretty much the exact opposite of the Mega Man DOS Remake, meaning everything is extremely loose and floaty. Also, the rather high movement speed on everything is how this usually runs (there's no option to adjust it, from what I can tell).

A good portion of the bosses in this game are rather lack-luster as well, save for some specific (glitch-ridden) traits on a distinct few. This intro boss is obviously way more bland than anything else, but he does give a good opportunity to show off another strange thing about this game: a parrying system against projectiles.

Ah, right. One thing I forgot to mention about the slide/dash in this game is that it's a bit glitchy (and exploitable) when taking damage. If you slide or dash into an enemy, you'll still get hurt, but you won't recoil at all. This can basically serve as a way of getting free invincibility time to bypass any clusters of enemies or other hazards.

Interesting...I think I remember seeing that "Magic Joe" enemy before, mainly from a sprite sheet for concept enemy designs in another fan-game that never saw completion (I can't remember the original creator's name, but I know it was on Deviantart). I have no idea if the creator of this game got permission to use them (or if it was open source to begin with), but I won't jump to conclusions just yet.

I don't know how it works exactly, but it seems like if you jump right as a projectile hits you, it'll bounce back (sort of like if you were using Proto Man's shield). Then again, this only works occasionally. Sometimes you'll still get hit, and sometimes you'll deflect projectiles by simply mashing the fire button. It just seems to play by its own rules.
<-- wut

Magic Star is one of the worst shield weapons I've ever come across (even more-so than the Police Shield from MM Rocks and the Tarot Shuffle from MM 25th). The hit-box on this thing is so misaligned that you practically have to take damage from anything you want to hit with it. Coupled with the fact that it can't block out projectiles (it immediately goes away and you take damage if one hits it), along with it automatically firing off in the direction you're facing after a set amount of time, it's downright mortifying that this isn't even the worst weapon in the game.

Dynamite Bot is easily the most annoying boss in this game. His main strategy is to basically run into you, along with speeding up tremendously every single time you hit him. He also has a move that stops time, which completely locks up your movements for several seconds (this effects you even during invincibility and recoil, which could easily give him two cheap shots in a row).

It's actually quite helpful in a lot of areas, considering most of these enemies aren't worth fighting. Nearly all of them take way too many shots to take down (even with most of the weapons), especially the Scorpion enemies - which is about 1 of the 5 or so different enemy types in this game.

As you can probably tell, this game was also made by someone whose first language isn't English. I don't have any issues with the notion of this, but if you're going to translate your game into another language that you might have some problems with, at least find someone who understands it better.
Thankfully, that doesn't happen here (even though he still glitches out/breaks the rules of the Dynamite Flash by suddenly moving while it's activated).

Mummy Bot here is pretty tame, aside from his projectiles. The sand tornados he fires will home in on you, meaning you're pretty much guaranteed to take a hit or two from them. The parry system is also pretty unreliable in stopping them (for obvious reasons).

Ape Quake is essentially a full screen enemy eraser, and is probably the second best weapon in the game. It has the usual traits of having a slightly lower ammo count (7 shots), but also deals high damage in turn (here, it's enough to kill most minor enemies with one use). The main drawback is that it can only hurt things on the ground (but then again, a good portion of the more annoying enemies in this game are ground-based anyways).

Of course, using the Ape Quake mostly nullifies that (but if you intend to buster duel him, it becomes far more frustrating). In any case, beating him gives you the Dynamite Flash, the best weapon in the game. It's basically the Flash Stopper from Mega Man 4. That's honestly the best description I can give on it, since it's literally almost an exact copy of it (not that I'm complaining though, since it's an awesome weapon to begin with).

E-Tanks in this game (or rather, "Cross Tanks") aren't exactly self-explanatory on which does what. There are three different types: Red restores your health, Green refills your ammo, and there's the Blue/Yellow one. I never found the last one at all in this game, but I'd be willing to make a safe bet that it's probably the equivalent of an M-Tank.

Speaking of the levels, there sadly isn't much to talk about with them. This intro stage is about as advanced as the levels get in this game: Plain layouts, almost no gimmicks, and the same few enemy types are constantly recycled through-out them. The only thing that some of the stages have going for them are the backgrounds and music (which even those can get bland at times).

Like I said before, this game has issues (and ones not just limited to sprites). Starting off however, we get a choice between the two main characters. Betabot plays sort of like a poor man's version of Bass. He has a rapid buster and a dash instead of a slide, the latter of which is nearly useless since you lose all momentum if you try to dash-jump. Betabot also seems to jump lower and falls quicker than Rockbot, which has now given me more than enough reasons to not use him for this playthrough.
Yes, the stage actually started before the music for the boss intro sequence was finished (and yes, he's using Guns N' Roses references as well).

Mage Bot is the shield-user of this game, and a rather annoying one at that. It's not so much due to his pattern, but rather due to a nasty glitch that can happen with this fight. If you pause the game while he has his shield up, the shield itself will disappear, but Mage Bot will suddenly be completely invincible - as if he were protected by the shield. The game apparently registers that he still has his shield up, and yet despite this, it never goes away. The only option you'd have left is to either die to him or restart the game.

Got to love how the Shield Attackers are susceptible to the Ape Quake at first, yet are somehow immune to it while turning around. Even the better weapons in this game have their (glitchy) faults, as you'll soon see with the Dynamite Flash as well.
Quality walking animation. 10/10

Desert Storm (not to be confused with Action 52's "Storm Over the Desert") is one of the few semi-decent weapons in this game. It has an average ammo count and deals moderate damage, but like Mummy Bot's version, it also homes in on enemies. The downside is that the projectiles may completely ignore your intended target and focus on another one. It mostly seems to depend on which enemy is the closest to you.
